stories.text:
Hey Hackers,
I've got a classic conundrum on my hands: While most of my architecture is about handling events, we've got the first few requests for stuff that's happening at regular intervals, or happens a certain amount of time after an event.
One example is follow-up pings after signup. We want to tell the user about additional features in the few days after they first sign up, so we want to emit messages 48 and 72 hours after sign up.
My question is whether lightweight serverless tools feel 'ready' to do these scheduled tasks, or if you're still using cron jobs to do stuff like this.
I should say that I'm aware of a third path that turns out to be pretty common: instead of follow up messages coming from our own stack, a signup would add someone to a 'campaign' in a CRM tool like Salesforce. That feels clunky, I'm not even an admin on our CRM, so I want to do it from inside my own tools.

stories.text:
Hi HN,

while building something entirely, I realized that there is a lack of tools to pick colors for websites and web apps. While there certainly is an abundance of tools for color palettes, but they mostly give you three to five bright or pastel colors. Not what you need for websites. For that, you need one or two primary colors, and then stuff like text color, background, and so on.

So, together with another web dev I built a small web tool that allows picking exactly the colors you need for web projects and live preview your palette on a selection of demo websites.

The first version of the tool is online at https://colorsforwebsites.com. Free and no sign up.

We are already using this to for early stage projects, so I hope this provides value for you as well. Of course we are also happy about any and all feedback.

Cheerz :)
stories.title: Show HN: A color palette design tool for websites
